name: rare earth element mine operation and beneficiation, ion adsorption clays | rare earth carbonate concentrate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23220/documentation

This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography of CN. China is the top producer of Rare Earth metals in the world (81.4%) (source USGS). This dataset refers to the mining and beneficiation activities (in-situ leaching) of ion adsorption clays spreading across seven southern provinces in China (Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Yunnan, and Zhejiang) in order to produce rare earth carbonate concentrate. The produced carbonate concentrate will then undergo roasting, calcination and solvent extraction in order to produce high purity individual rare earth oxides. Compared to the other production pathways of rare earth oxides in China, this pathway produces 15 individual REOs (cerium, europium, lanthanum, neodymium, samarium, ytterbium, yttrium, dysprosium, erbium, gadolinium, holmium, lutetium, praseodymium, terbium and thulium oxide.;Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Currently, mining and processing of rare earth elements is predominantly carried out in China, where they are extracted mainly via open pit mining of bastnäsite and/or monazite deposits or the leaching of ion-adsorption clays.;Modelling approach: This dataset was created using the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018).

The activity starts with the mining of the clays.

The activitity ends with the production of rare earth carbonate concentrate..

No allocation is applied.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography of CN. Since ion-adsorptions clays are found and mined in other parts of the world (South America and Africa), this process is considered applicable to other parts of the world.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography of CN and it is used as the best availble rep-resentation of the GLO. The technologies information described are taken from the corresponding CN dataset. Ion-adsorption clays deposits from South China usually contain 0.04−0.25% REOs. Despite their low concentration and reserves, increased production of REEs from these deposits has been reported over the last 10 years, due to easiness of mining and concentrating through through the use of weak acids. For this reason, in-situ leaching has become the prominent method for REE extraction from ion adsorption clays. Ammonium sulfate is used in or-der to leach the ion adsorption clays, with the precipitation of the leachate occurring through the use of ammo-nium bicarbonate or oxalic acid. The resulting carbonate concentrate contains approximately 45% REOs.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography CN. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly. China dominates the market for rare earth element production (81.4% according to USGS minerals yearbook 2016).
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is based on the following publication: Arshi, P. S., Vahidi, E., & Zhao, F. (2018). Behind the Scenes of Clean Energy: The Environmental Footprint of Rare Earth Products. ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering, 6(3), 3311-3320. doi:10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b03484.   
All exchanges from/ to the environment and from/to the technosphere were calculated using the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university. This excel-based software acts as a supporting tool to the abovementioned publication. Individual exchanges such as sulfidic tailings and wastewater which were not contained in the original datasets have been added for completness purposes and their calculation is based on mass balance.

flow.name: rare earth carbonate concentrate
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

exchanges.description: Value taken from the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university (more information on the sampling procedure) and corresponds to the production of 1 kg of rare earth carbonate concentrate.
